Hi you two. I have been watching your videos for a few years now and really enjoy them. However, here is some constructive criticism: The Vagus nerve is a parasympatic nerve. The "fight or flight" response is triggered by the sympatic nervous system, not the parasymatic one. Activity of the Vagus nerve would for example lower the heart rate, not raise it. (However suppression/lowered activity of the vagal heart innervation during "fight or flight" situations can "support" (or at least not counteract) the higher heart rate (+ further responses to fear/stress) which are activated by the sympatic nerves. In this way the Vagus does in some way, if you want, play a role in "fight or flight" as you call it.)
You should maybe make an annotation to correct that... I guess it doesn't really make a difference to the topic of the video, but it's still misinformation.
Also, technically, the enteric nervous system is not really scientifically called a second brain as far as I know...!? But I see how that makes for a great title ;) And I completely agree that the connections between brain and intestines are fascinating, especially how ours bowel bacteria may influence our behaviours.
As this is something that has still not been fully understood/unravelled by science, I am excited to see what we will find out about it in the future :) Greetings from Germany

This video has a big error. The vagus nerve has parasympathetic outputs NOT sympathetic. So the vagus is in charge of "rest and digest" functions. "Fight or flight" sympathetic neurons come from the spinal cord. Those are the ones that speed up heart rate, increase breathing rate etc. The function of your organ is a result of the balance between the two systems. In a fight or flight situation, sympathetic neurons send more signals while parasympathetic signals would decrease.

Autism isn't a result of bad gut bacteria, although that does contribute to the symptoms. Neurological research indicates that autism affects the structure of your entire nervous system from top to bottom. So, autistics like me have a head-brain AND a gut-brain that are wired differently from non-autistic people. This different wiring may make the gut more hospitable to the wrong bacteria, mess up digestion and generally make us miserable. However, a fecal transfer or change in diet to fix the gut flora doesn't cure autism, it just makes some of the symptoms more manageable in some (but not all) autistic people.
